page.title: 09LOCAL HISTORY
page.content: Chorlton is probably derived from the Saxon CEORLA-TUN, an enclosure of the peasants or settlers or from CEOLFRIP-TUN, meaning Ceolfrip's enclosure. In either case the name represents a clearing by Saxons in a forest probably a mixture of oak and willow. Stretford probably comes from the DE STRAET, a paved road and ford. The De Traffords were lords of the manor of Stretford, Trafford and Barton for over 900 years from the early 11th century, but moved away after the opening of the Manchester Ship Canal.
